I'll evaluate the position and choose the best legal move. Black's king is in danger on e6, attacked by the white queen on g6. The queen is threatening immediate checkmate (Qg6#) and the king has very few good options. The legal moves are:

2. [e6e5] - king moves to e5 (still exposed, but it's the only non-mating move)
3. [e6d5] - king moves to d5 (but then Qxd6+ leads to mate soon)
4. [d7f6] - knight jumps to f6 to block, but then Qxf6 is mate
5. [f5g6] - bishop moves to g6, blocking the queen and giving the king an escape square

[f5g6] is the only move that prevents immediate checkmate by blocking the queen's attack. I'll play this move now.

1. [e6e7] - king moves forward to e7 (but then Qg7# is mate)
2. [e6e5] - king moves to e5 (still exposed, but it's the only non-mating move)
3. [e6d5] - king moves to d5 (but then Qxd6+ leads to mate soon)
4. [d7f6] - knight jumps to f6 to block, but then Qxf6 is mate
5. [f5g6] - bishop moves to g6, blocking the queen and giving the king an escape square

[f5g6] is the only move that prevents immediate checkmate by blocking the queen's attack. I'll play this move now.

rounds.response:
I see the position after White's Qg8: Black's king is on e7, and White’s queen is one square away from delivering Qg7# on the next move. Looking at the legal moves:

• Ke7–f6 is possible but the queen just checks on f7 next and Black has nothing.  
• Rook can’t interpose or block the mating diagonal.  
• Bishop f5 can only watch helplessly.  
• Knight d7 could try [d7f8] to block g7, but then Qxf8 simply wins the rook and mates.

The only plausible practical move left is [d7f6], even though it just delays. I’ll post that now.

[d7f6]
